pros: Hind sight is 20/20. There are none. So sorry.

review_title: Instuctor, Applied Commerce and Management Education
pros: Students are generally energetic and curious - what more could you want? How about sensitive and caring management ? The forty-four day annual leave is wonderful!  It's enough to lead an employee to overlook the other shortcomings of the union: remember the Manitoba Government is the ultimate payer so collective bargaining can come shuddering to a halt at any time.
cons: A tyrannical management style is pervasive. At the lower levels of the hierarchy, there are no velvet gloves and abuse of dedicated instructors is fairly common. (There is NO career path for instructors. Advancement in pay grade means transferring into an administration stream so the administrators generally view instructors as competition and students as cattle.)

review_title: Lots of room for creativity but internal career opportunities are slim
pros: free fitness facilities, overall good working environment, restaurants on-site, training and development available, great locations
cons: limited career opportunities for those who don't know "people' but for those who do, you can move up or try different departments and even get management positions; compensation could be improved; executive management team and management in general should reflect the make up of the student body and community - you need to diversify your management a little bit - seems quite restrictive for qualified  visible minorities to obtain senior positions.

job_title: Instructor, College Or University in Winnipeg, MB
pros: Autonomy to make new decisions, amazing benefits and pension, plenty of vacation, great coworkers, opportunities to try new ideas and progress learning in Manitoba and Canada.
cons: It's a big organization, sometimes things fall through the cracks or take longer than we would like.
